DataElement.preferredName: Memorial Symptom Assessment Scale (MSAS) 10-18 Score Other Symptom Severity Memorial Symptom Assessment Scale Severity Score 4 Point Scale
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A patient-rated questionnaire designed to evaluate the prevalence, characteristics, and distress to children with cancer aged 10-18. This 30-question instrument was adapted from a previously-validated adult version._A number or range of numeric values measuring performance, function, quality, or ability._A symptom that is not among those been previously noted._Severity; used of the degree of something undesirable e.g. pain or weather._Numeric scores from 1 (Slight) to 4 (Very Severe) on a Likert scale used on the Memorial Symptom Assessment Scale questionnaire.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Memorial Symptom Assessment Scale (MSAS) 10-18 Score Other Symptom Severity
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A patient-rated questionnaire designed to evaluate the prevalence, characteristics, and distress to children with cancer aged 10-18. This 30-question instrument was adapted from a previously-validated adult version._A number or range of numeric values measuring performance, function, quality, or ability._A symptom that is not among those been previously noted._Severity; used of the degree of something undesirable e.g. pain or weather.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A patient-rated questionnaire designed to evaluate the prevalence, characteristics, and distress to children with cancer aged 10-18. This 30-question instrument was adapted from a previously-validated adult version.

Concepts.definition: A patient-rated questionnaire designed to evaluate the prevalence, characteristics, and distress to children with cancer aged 10-18. This 30-question instrument was adapted from a previously-validated adult version.

Property.preferredDefinition: A symptom that is not among those been previously noted.:Severity; used of the degree of something undesirable e.g. pain or weather.:A number or range of numeric values measuring performance, function, quality, or ability.

Concepts.definition: A symptom that is not among those previously noted.
Used of the degree of something undesirable e.g. pain or weather; also, strictness.
A number or range of numeric values measuring performance, function, quality, or ability.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Process and results associated with self-reported measures and instruments, surveys, other tools

DataElementConcept.origin: MSAS 10-18:  Memorial Symptom Assessment Scale (10-18). J. Collins, et al. Journal of Pain and Symptom Management. 2000 May; 19(5): 363-377

ValueDomain.preferredName: Memorial Symptom Assessment Scale Severity Score 4 Point Scale
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Numeric scores from 1 (Slight) to 4 (Very Severe) on a Likert scale used on the Memorial Symptom Assessment Scale questionnaire.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Exceedingly intense or unpleasant in degree, quality or extent.

Concepts.definition: Exceedingly intense or unpleasant in degree, quality or extent.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Intensely bad or unpleasant in degree, quality or extent.

Concepts.definition: Intensely bad or unpleasant in degree, quality or extent.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The quality of being within reasonable or average limits; not excessive or extreme.

Concepts.definition: The quality of being within reasonable or average limits; not excessive or extreme.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Small or little in size, quantity, or degree.

Concepts.definition: Small or little in size, quantity, or degree.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Process and results associated with self-reported measures and instruments, surveys, other tools

Concepts.definition: An ordered reference standard used to measure incremental changes.

ValueDomain.origin: MSAS-SF:Memorial Symptom Assessment Scale Short Form.Chang VT, et.al., Cancer. 2000 Sep 1;89(5):1162-71.

ReferenceDocuments.name: How severe was the symptom us
ReferenceDocuments.description: How severe was the symptom usually?
